content.raw: I'm wondering if maybe adding some debug and/or zero-optimization flags to the `COVERAGE` build configuration could eliminate some compiler optimizations that might be tricking the coverage report. But I don't know enough about how code coverage actually works under the hood to know whether that would help anything.
content.html: I'm wondering if maybe adding some debug and/or zero-optimization flags to the COVERAGE build configuration could eliminate some compiler optimizations that might be tricking the coverage report. But I don't know enough about how code coverage actually works under the hood to know whether that would help anything.

pullrequest.title: Make line coverage by default, add separate coverage-branch target

content.raw: I did a bit of investigating and documented on issue #28, I think the main issue is that codecov doesn't consider partial hits for the total coverage. Besides that, there are a few instances of weird lines reported as partially hit but it's not clear how that could be possible.
content.html: I did a bit of investigating and documented on issue #28, I think the main issue is that codecov doesn't consider partial hits for the total coverage. Besides that, there are a few instances of weird lines reported as partially hit but it's not clear how that could be possible.

pull_request.title: Make line coverage by default, add separate coverage-branch target

pullrequest.title: Make line coverage by default, add separate coverage-branch target

content.raw:
I've definitely found the new coverage reports to be perplexing and frustrating, but I think we should investigate the cause of the negative reports before we just wipe them out.

If it's something that could be fixed by changing our compile flags or tweaking our coverage configuration in some way, then I would strongly prefer to do that. If it's not something that would be straightforward to fix, then this is probably a well-known problem, and we should be able to refer to online discussions about it to justify turning off this feature.

I think the question is: Who wants to spend the time to investigate, and how much time is worth spending on this?
content.html:
I've definitely found the new coverage reports to be perplexing and frustrating, but I think we should investigate the cause of the negative reports before we just wipe them out.

If it's something that could be fixed by changing our compile flags or tweaking our coverage configuration in some way, then I would strongly prefer to do that. If it's not something that would be straightforward to fix, then this is probably a well-known problem, and we should be able to refer to online discussions about it to justify turning off this feature.

I think the question is: Who wants to spend the time to investigate, and how much time is worth spending on this?

content.html:
I tried disabling branch coverage reports on codecov without success:

#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-math/commits/a1482c1f395bbf0c4ac02858b90348626b4dcb80

I'm fine with removing coverage. Another thing we could try is adding a cmake variable which allows turning branch coverage on in case someone wants to run it locally

pull_request.title: Make line coverage by default, add separate coverage-branch target

pullrequest.title: Make line coverage by default, add separate coverage-branch target

content.raw:
Without this branch, ign-math4 is listed as having about [75% coverage](https://codecov.io/bb/ignitionrobotics/ign-math/branch/ign-math4)

With this branch, it shows [over 99% coverage](https://codecov.io/bb/ignitionrobotics/ign-math/branch/no_branch_coverage)

* the test branch is based on `ign-math4` with a modified pipeline: #!/ignitionrobotics/ign-math/commits/249bb6ff9aa7d2573582dd1fce6640a4d03eb27f
content.html:
Without this branch, ign-math4 is listed as having about 75% coverage

With this branch, it shows over 99% coverage

  • the test branch is based on ign-math4 with a modified pipeline: #!/ignitionrobotics/ign-math/commits/249bb6ff9aa7d2573582dd1fce6640a4d03eb27f
